{{WikiProject Catholicism}}
The proposal to merge with [[Papal infallibility]] does not make sense because most dogmatic definitions are written by councils of bishops rather than by popes. [[User:Michael Hardy|Michael Hardy]] ([[User talk:Michael Hardy|talk]]) 18:00, 29 April 2010 (UTC)
While Michael presents an interesting view on a possible paradox within Catholicism, I believe with all due respect and total appreciation for Michael's desire to improve the page, having read Wkipedia's guidlines and mission, Michael's point is irrelevant to the problem that makes this pages mention of papal infallibility innapropriate for the page. As a veteran journalist Ifind that most often this does not happen because the original author intends to impose an opinion on others, but rather stems from an honest mistake or a completely understandable lack of awareness of how to phrase things. Many writers much more skilled than myself make this mistake because of not having the background to know how to phrase things objectively, that someone like myself must adhere to daily for my newspaper.
After a second thorough inspection the problem is the author has stated a belief of the religion as a foregone conclusion and therefore was unable to provide a source as none exists that would prove a belief of a religion.
The article needs to be rewritten to make the point that Catholics believe that all Christians are subject to Papal Infallibility whether or not the Christian as an individual or whole denomination chooses to recognize it. Then a source in Catholic literature would be appropriate to verify that this is the belief of Catholicism. I can try to find that infoprmation in Cathlolic literature and I believe it is then necessary to remain objective by citing the verse in the Christian bible claims no man is infallible and since the Pope is a man other denominations believe it would be borderline blasphemous to their belief that only God is infallible.
In it's current state this page completely disregards Wikipedia's standard for religious objectivity <ref>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:RNPOV</ref>
I believe the most appropriate course of action would be to delete the entire article and simply define "Dogmatic Definition" and cite a source for the definition.
[[User:KevinHightower|KevinHightower]] ([[User talk:KevinHightower|talk]]) 23:01, 21 August 2011 (UTC)KevinHightower
